bioghist.p: Charles C. Gillispie (b. 1918) is a historian of science specializing in France 1760-1820. He received his bachelor's degree from Wesleyan University and did graduate work at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University. He joined the faculty of Princeton University in 1947, where he founded both the undergraduate and graduate programs in the history of science; he is now professor emeritus. He was awarded the Balzan Prize in history and philosophy of science in 1997. He was the editor of the Dictionary of Scientific Biography, and his publications include The Edge of Objectivity (1960), Pierre-Simon Laplace, 1749-1827: A Life in Exact Science (1997), and Science and Polity in France: The Revolutionary and Napoleonic Years (2004).

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Charles Gillispie's research notes, reprints, and copies of texts and manuscripts related to his work on 18th and 19th century science in France. Many of the texts and manuscripts are in French, and are present here in the form of photocopies and microfilm. The collection also includes some transcriptions by Gillispie, and his manuscript notes on the original works. In addition to the research materials, there are some drafts of articles by Gillispie, lecture notes on the history of science in France and in America, and several dissertations on the history of science by others.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
